History_of_Present_Illness: 42 yof with no sig. PMH presenting with acute onset abdominal x several hours. Patient reports chronic, periodic abdominal pain x several months. Workup included CT abdomen which showed ileitis and colonoscopy with biopsy which was unrevealing. Stool studies to date have also been unremarkable. She describes the pain as crampy, lasting several seconds before resolving, targeting mid-lower abdomen. She denies any weight loss, fevers, chills, nausea or diarrhea. Each episode lasts around 8 hours before resolving. She cannot identify a clear trigger. GI has been following.
Family_history: Great aunt who may have had Crohn's disease. Mother with GERD.
Physical_Exam: VS: 98.1   98.4   62-63   98-104/61-62   16   100 RA - General: NAD, A + O x 3, pleasant - HEENT: supple, no LAD, OP clear - Heart: RRR, no MRG - Lungs: CTAB, no WRR - Abdomen: soft, mildly TTP periumbilical epigastric, no RG, ABS - Extremities: WWP, DP 2+, NT, no E
Discharge_Medications: 1. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 5 days. Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Flagyl 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a day for 5 days: Do not drink while taking this medication or it will make ___ very ill. Disp:*15 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
Other_Discharge_Information: Mrs. ___, ___ were admitted to the hospital for evaluation of your abdominal pain. CT scan of your abdomen was performed which showed inflammation in the wall of your ileum. A urinalysis was also performed which showed that ___ did not have a urinary tract infection. Gastroenterology was consulted and would like ___ to continue on antibiotics for the next 5 days. They would also like ___ to eat a bland diet consisting of things like bran, rice, applesauce, and toast. They are going to defer colonoscopy at this time and will follow up with ___ as an outpatient.
